posts.name: Enishan Eren Gücük
posts.cooked: Hı everyone I am lead programmer 7536 we are building new robot for off season. We buy Limelight 3G and use turret but ı dont know how can ı turret scan with limelight.

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Is the limelight mounted to the turret?

posts.name: Enishan Eren Gücük
posts.cooked: yes we are planning to mounting the turret

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: What is “turret scanning”? Looking for a target with the limelight?

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
By turret scan, I’m assuming you mean turn a turret left and right until the LL sees a target.

There’s a few ways that come to mind, in order of increasing difficulty:

Simply control the turret [motor] until it reaches x encoder value (the left or right max of the turret), then turn the other way, repeat. This could be adapted to run only while x button is pressed.

Simply control the turret [motor] until it reaches x encoder value (the left or right max of the turret), then turn the other way, repeat. This could be adapted to run only while x button is pressed.

PID loop: same thing as #1 , but you have a PID loop controlling the turret motor, rather than looking directly at the encoder value. This loop will ensure that your turret is facing the value that the program thinks it’s facing. You could also adapt this solution to only run while a button is pressed, or some other requirements.

PID loop: same thing as #1 , but you have a PID loop controlling the turret motor, rather than looking directly at the encoder value. This loop will ensure that your turret is facing the value that the program thinks it’s facing. You could also adapt this solution to only run while a button is pressed, or some other requirements.

Localization / Heading: This involves knowing your robot’s heading, or x-y value on the field. The idea is that you know one of those two values, and you know where your target is. With that, you can use another PID loop to set your turret angle to where the robot thinks the target should be, and then once the LL sees it, rely on that rather than the estimation.

Localization / Heading: This involves knowing your robot’s heading, or x-y value on the field. The idea is that you know one of those two values, and you know where your target is. With that, you can use another PID loop to set your turret angle to where the robot thinks the target should be, and then once the LL sees it, rely on that rather than the estimation.

LMK if you want code examples of any of these, I’d be happy to write some
